Having seen Larry play at every gig we've been to since Joshua Tree at Wembley in 1987, his absence was weird. That said, our night at the Sphere was incredible and Bram did a brilliant job. The aspect of that venue I didn't like was the large amount of casual fans who didn't even know the words to a lot of the songs. When Bono held the mic up to the audience to sing along to One, the silence was embarrasing. I've seen Fat Elvis on the Strip get more audience involvement. Listening to a group of very well heeled 40 somethings talk about the show as we walked back to our hotel, it was clear for them it was just another night out in Vegas. When one of the ladies asked the group which was their favourite song, one shouted 'Sunday Sunday' while another admitted that she didn't know any of the song titles. This would not have been any different - with or without Larry.

I just returned from this show and thoroughly enjoyed it, as has pretty much everyone whose seen it. As a long time fan of the band (since War), I never give up the opportunity to see them live one more time, because you never know when it will be the last. I saw Rush, Clockwork Angels, but didn't make the effort to see R40. I'm kicking myself now. I also fulfilled a lifelong dream to see Joe Strummer live with Mescaleros. Was it Joe with The Clash? No, a completely new but amazing group of of largely unknown (unknown to me at least) musicians who "got" Joe. It was in a small club in Toronto, with a few thousand people, but Joe and the band were cooking. A month later, he died. So treat yourself and see U2 one more time, because you never know if it will be the last time.

I hated when they picked on Trump, not being US citizens, and then later when they promoted abortion for Ireland, as I hate when artists and sports get involved in politics. Hello from Ireland and, yes, I completely agree. I've been a U2 head for decades. I have every album, every DVD, the books and the memories. But this LV gig is about one thing and one thing only: Cash. Larry's absence should have been the signal to call it off, even if it was going to cost them. Without Larry U2 is three-quarters of an iconic band and three-quarters isn't good enough. No disrespect intended to the fine stand-in drummer. Instead of trying to cream more money, the band should have got themselves back to the studio to start work on a new album. Unless the well has run dry. Has it? Instead, they issued a double album of old songs with a new makeover. First U2 album I didn't bother buying. It feels like we're seeing the beginning of the end and it had to come some time. Nothing is permanent except death. Anyway, it was a great ride and their best albums are still the best albums rock has to offer. Pity they chose do their swan song in a place that embodies everything Bono professes to detest.
The ONLY thing stopping us from instantly grabbing a ticket and burning money on the ticket, hotel, week unpaid off work, etc...was the Larry Mullen factor. In my opinion, for every band or artist there comes a time when you are running out of ideas. Of course you always get songs together somehow but it's nothing special anymore or you repeat yourself. I think U2 have reached this point. The albums of the 80s and 90s were phenomenal. What should come after that? The bar is raised higher and higher and at some point it doesn't work anymore or you get tired of pushing it further and further. On the last U2 albums I couldn't hear that earlier spirit anymore. The songs became predictable and no more big surprises. When I heard "Pride" or "Bad" for the first time, I got goose bumps. But you can't expect such ideas from musicians all the time and I think they want to cash in again before they stop. If you're honest, most people would do that.
If I'm going to see U2 perform, it's because of the band members. I don't care if they roll on stage in wheel chairs, because I'm there to see them play their music, not some substitute. Besides, nobody can play Larry Mullen Jr's drum licks like he can. NOBODY!! Can you dig it?
Music is such an *intensely personal* aspect of an individual's identity that many people get upset/indignant/outraged when a band changes things around.  Remember when Michael McDonald joined the Doobie Brothers when Tom Johnston took a break?  It was like The Holocaust for some people.  Music is a business, and it goes way beyond four chaps in a garage pounding out some tunes until the neighbors call the cops.  We as fans don't own our favorite bands; we don't get to vote on how they run their business.  But we can vote with our money--we buy their stuff or we don't.

From what I've read, the band committed to this residency pre-COVID; COVID pushed the opening of this new venue back by several years. Whether for health and/or other reasons (read an October or November 2022 Washington Post interview where Larry almost suggests he's considering leaving the band because it's no longer enjoyable for him), Larry has said no touring in 2023. Other band members have said Larry will talk more when/if he's ready to do so. So Larry might be (for reasons apart from this Las Vegas residency)  considering leaving the band, but the rest of the band is not ready to retire. I hope I'm wrong on this. But lend no credence to the idea that the band *must* get back on the road; that's just standard Bono spin.  And is this a fumble? Yes, but the more appropriate comparison is to doing the Kmart promo for POP and opening the POPmart tour in Las Vegas.

As a 29 year old fan I have to say Achtung Baby is in fact my favorite album of all time- but I realize this isn't an opinion I've ever heard someone my age express ðŸ¤£  I share your feelings about this residency, but also have other concerns. Larry Mullen not playing is really unfortunate, and as much as they say it's just because he has to have back surgery- I can't help but wonder if that is cover for the fact that he might be burned on out on playing with U2. Sad as it is no band lasts forever, and he has made comments recently (and in the past) that suggest he might be ready to move on, apart from whatever health issues he is facing. I think in 2010 he said "I don't see myself at 65 playing in Vegas"....   Aside from Larry I have real concerns about whether Bono is up to the task of singing these songs again. If you've seen any of their limited live material of the last 3-4 years, it is clear his voice is not what it used to be at all- he can't hit any of the high notes he used to. After he completely lost his voice at a show on the last tour, and hearing how limited his range is in recent performances, I just don't know how he can pull off the big stadium belting rock voice that is required for this material. The Songs of Surrender release shows that even in a controlled, studio environment, he isn't able to sing the songs like he used to. Pretty much all of the songs are either lowered by many keys, or he just doesn't go for the high notes at all. U2 is a stadium band, and if Bono doesn't have the voice to fill these stadiums, I don't think there will be much steam left in U2's live shows. Breaks my heart to say it, I've been obsessed with this band for 15 years now, can sing & play most of their biggest songs on every instrument. U2 is a big part of the reason I love music so much today, but it might be time for them to move on ðŸ˜¢

This is slightly misguided in that Larry MJ wasn't particularly happy with the direction of the rhythm section - and more specifically the drumming - from Achtung's producers, Daniel Lanois and Brian Eno.  He wanted something closer to Joshua Tree.  So we have Lanois and Eno to thank for the industrial sounding and more dance influenced beats on that album, some of which reflected it being recorded in Berlin.  Yes, such a talented drummer was easily able to emulate their wishes, but he didn't inspire the concept of drumming on the album.  Bands often slot someone else in when one member is ill or injured, it doesn't feel particularly controversial to me.  You couldn't obviously do it without Paul or Dave, sorry Bono or the Edge!  However longer term let's hope he recovers and still has the verve to keep going.  He is a drumming legend.

It seems more that Larry is a victim of organizational politics.   It appears corporate maneuvering and aligning by the other business interests both inside and outside the U2 corporation has yielded a new power structure different from the previous incarnation: the 4 band members and their manager Paul McGuinness operating as equal owners.  Now it seems the drummer has found himself in a severely diminished position despite his being a principal corporate owner and the founder of the organization itself.   This is evidenced by a recent public statement where he compared U2's internal management mechanism to a politburo.  He called it a benevolent dictatorship, and he said he was now questioning his ability and willingness to continue as an active member of the touring group(maybe even as a corporate owner).   While health reasons is the official narrative, his absence from the Vegas residency seems to be much more the product or symptom of some type of non-public internal power struggle amongst the principal partners and their corporate partners.

In general I don t think that a temporary replacement of a musician is a big drama under cercain circumstance. In case a tour is running and a drummer is ill and can t play for maybe two weeks - I think this was not a problem to replace the drummer for the running gigs during that time to be able to continue the tour. Of course this drummer needed to be able to play the songs of the tour in a good and acceptable quality. And it was nessecary to be honest with this problem and to say "yes we are playing this gig without Larry, because ... and we could find a fantastic drummer who will play tonight as replacement." - Of course it was impossible to replace Bono and maybe also very difficult to do this with the Edge, because they are much more present in the view of the audience. I'll be completely honest: I'm really not the biggest U2 fan. At all. I think they are (along with The Police and The Doors) one of the most overhyped and underwhelming bands of all time.   That said, it is not U2 without Larry Mullen, Jr. As when Bill Berry left R.E.M., they forged on, but it really felt like the "Buck/Mills/Stipe" project. It wasn't the same band. You can say what you want about Steven Adler as a person, but  "Appetite For Destruction" is as great as it is because of him.  A great drummer is worth his or her weight in gold.   There's a reason why LZ disbanded when Bonham died.  The same reason Rush called it quits when Neil died.  You don't replace those guys.  I'm not saying Mullen is on the aforementioned drummers' level. I'm saying if you take out his sound, it completely alters the feel of the band.
How much money would it take for me to spend many months in Vegas playing old U2 songs? Not as much as you'd think. Sounds fun. If Larry's ok with it (and being paid to sit home and recover?) then just enjoy the show, man. I also saw them in '92, but for the life of me, I can't remember where. Probably Chicago?
I think it's astonishing that this band has some need for additional capitol at this stage of their lives. Of course, this is what the LV residency is all about. There is NO other explanation. I believed iTunes "free album" fiasco was a glitch. A big glitch, but a comparatively small hick up in what's been a truly dream career. Personally, I've not really been into their music this century, but I was all over the first twenty years of it. I've seen theme a number of times, including the Zoo TV tour, which as Rick stated, was phenomenal. U2 should now be managing their exit strategy, which, let's face it, isn't that far off in the future,  by carefully picking and choosing releases and shows that keep their "fabled rock band" status in tact. But now, by making some bizarre money-grubbing decision, they have elected to squander pretty much all of that legend equity for a residency in one of the tackiest places on earth to see a show. Blue Man Group, Penn and Teller, Carrot Top and... U2. Damn...

agreed...comes down to greed. ðŸ˜Š
@RickBeato I just don't understand the point of them doing this (aside from the massive pay day... which, by any reasonable assessment of their wealth, they don't need). Sure, it's easy and somewhat naÃ¯ve for someone like myself and most/all of us who are not in a multi-platinum selling, supper successful, legendary band to sit around on the internet and say, "well what you should do is..." Frankly, it reminds me of a bunch of guys at the bar, three beers deep, screaming at the TV about how, whoever on the Yankees, just needs to do XYZ in order to turn his season around. Be that as it may, it's hard for me see how the band thought that this, and frankly the series of choices they've made in recent years, would accomplish what they ostensibly say they'd like to accomplish. Bono has gone on and on about his desire to stay relevant. He's backed off from that sentiment a little bit in the last year or so, but it's clear that he'd love a re-do of the early 2000's (or mid-80's, or early 90's). I think they're realizing that's not going to happen.   At that point a band in their position has two options: blow it all up and do something fresh and interesting (which they've done and it was AWESOME *cough* Achtung *cough* Baby) or lean into the machine and milk it. Unfortunately they're choosing the latter.  They did the whole "let's play our biggest album on tour" thing (credit where credit is due, I saw them on the JT tour and it was awesome, regardless it doesn't exactly say "we're here, we're relevant, listen to us!") Their latest "album" is just an acoustic re-recording their old songs...changing some lyrics... I don't know, who cares?  I wasn't sure how much louder they could scream "we've run out of ideas and have no clue where to go from here!" until this gem of an idea came about.   All that's to say, here's my armchair, BS, no one cares, screaming at the TV three-beers deep opinion on one of my favorite band's recent rash (like nearly a decade's worth...) of completely tone-deaf decisions: You did it, not once but multiple times, do it again - tear it all down and start over. Screw the money, you're richer than Croesus. Forget competing with pop stars,  or being "relevant."  Forget the stupid gimmicks like Las Vegas spheres or iPhone security intrusions. Don't go to Las Vegas and do the whole "play a hit album back to front" thing without a founding and pivotal member of the band just to suck money away from whoever happens to be rolling through town. You're better than jockeying for a spot on the vacationing boomer's post-buffet night out (or at least you should be). Competing for that dollar against Maroon 5 and Garth Brooks actually does the OPPOSITE of what you have openly said you want to do. So ignore all that nonsense and focus on making meaningful art that makes sense to you and take the risk that it, the music - not some gimmick- may or may not make sense to others as well. It's what you did in the 90s when you were in post-Soviet Berlin and when you were hanging out in the East Village to catch Jeff Buckley shows. You just cared about art and putting your fingerprint on it. Do it again. There's nothing to say you can't.

I think, to a certain extent, having replacement members for a tour or a residency can become inevitable as bands age. The cause can be anything from health problems, to regular band animosity, to fatigue. People handle things differently, and at different speeds.Â   I remember a roadie having to play bass at one point on a tour because Adam was having, if I remember correctly, alcohol related issues and missed some shows. I remember him saying it was a wake up call for him regarding not only his place in the band, but also the fact that a roadie could step in and play his parts. The experience helped him not only sober up, but he re-dedicated himself to improving his skill on the bass.

What U2 is is not up to you to decide but to them. Makes me think of people going round saying, "Pink Floyd without Syd Barret has no future" or, "The Rolling Stones without Brian Jones are not The Rolling Stones", or even, "We want Pete!" Probably people did say it at the time but in retrospect it may seem absurd. And yes, Larry is important for the band, but maybe we have just got too used to the formula of those four men, like the world has got used to the formula of Coca Cola. Achtung Baby is not centring around Larry Mullen Jr, it's a complete falsehood. Obviously, they were all important for the album, but none more so perhaps than Bono and The Edge, without whom the "sound of four men chopping down the joshua tree" would never have been heard. Larry Mullen was at first opposed to going in a completely different direction. I can't help feeling that you are so enraged by their going on the trip without Larry that you forget these central facts.

I used to say that there were only three bands who've been together for 40 years or more without ever changing members from the first album.  ZZ Top, whose debut came out in 1971 had the same tres hombres until Dusty Hill's passing in 2021.  King's X same three guys since 1980 (with two different additional rhythm guitarists as The Edge between 1980-83) put out their first album together as Sneak Preview in 1984; debut King's X album in 1988; same three guys put out their most recent album last year!  U2, same four guys since 1976 (with two additional second guitarists including The Edge's brother in the first two years), with a touring keyboardist for the past 20 years and now a fill-in drummer?  I am unaware of ZZ Top or King's X ever being augmented or having fill-ins and/or additional touring musicians.  I know that lots of bands have (AC/DC, Aerosmith, Black Sabbath, Cheap Trick, Deep Purple, The Eagles, Journey, Judas Priest, Kansas, KISS, Led Zeppelin [post-Bonham], Ozzy, Pink Floyd, Queen, Queensryche, Styx, Toto, UFO, Van Halen, The Who, Yes, et al) but these three bands are legendary for the consistency of the founding members.  I will add Rush with the honorable mention of John Rutsey on drums before and up to their debut, but Neil Peart did the tour for that album and it was the same trio until his death.  I saw ZZ Top about 25 years ago and while it was cool to see them again in 2022, it really wasn't quite the same without Dusty Hill.  I have only seen U2 three times (War, UF and JT) but I feel like those four are irreplaceable - like The Beatles, The Doors and Led Zeppelin. Sometimes The end isn't coming It's not coming The end is here Sometimes  ...and I thought "that sounds so strange" but then it dawned on me.  I think "The end isn't coming" is alluding to the creative process.  The song writing process. Larry Mullen Jr. has ruled himself out from touring for all of 2023.  Under normal circumstances, I think there's little question that the band would take the year off for Larry.  Unfortunately, if they want to continue playing at the level they are accustomed to for some years to come, the circumstances pretty much dictate that they need to get playing asap.  It's an understatement to say that U2 shows are epic productions.  Beyond that aspect, their sets are generally over two hours long.  They are in their 60's and they haven't played a show in over three years.  Given the incredible live performance level that the band has maintained for 40+ years, fans nor the band members themselves (especially) would be satisfied with a decline in quality.  It's no different than being an athlete.  The older one gets, the more work is required to maintain "game fitness".  Practicing in the studio or the jam space is just not the same thing.  I agree, the ad is a bit of an odd move, but I completely understand why the band is choosing to push on without Larry at this point.  They have to.

The one that *really* winds me up, and for the same reasons you've expressed Rick, is Queen.  Queen, for 20 years, was Fred, Brian, Rog and John.   Queen+ means _those four guys_ ... plus someone else (e.g. Bowie, Jackson).  For Brian and Rog to bill themselves as 'Queen' is as illogical as Macca and Ringo billing themselves as 'The Beatles'.  But, sadly, not all fans are created equal.   The vast majority lack depth of discernment, and see a U2 or Queen gig as simply an excuse to boogie in the same room as some rich celebrities on a stage. They're motivated by the same desire for vicarious greatness as those who seek to be photographed with, say, the Dalai Lama.  Kinda nauseating actually.

R.E.M. were never the same band without drummer Bill Berry - but the problem was the new albums.  They were still an awesome live band.  U2 can still sound awesome with someone else playing the drum parts that Larry Mullen Jr. wrote.  They're still his parts, but someone else can play them and no one will notice the difference.   The bigger question would be whether U2 should make new records without him, and this is different from R.E.M. too.  Bill Berry left when R.E.M. was at the height of its powers (even though I personally prefer the IRS years),  but U2 already stopped making great albums years ago.

Now, even 20-30 years later I can't stand U2 and really dislike their music and hearing Bono's voice is like fingernails on a chalk board.

The Joshua Tree album came out, at perhaps, the most pivotal moment in my life, after the death of my first husband. And it was almost, uncannily, autobiographical. I can't begin to tell you of how much that album meant to me. And I found myself traveling alone throughout the SW, at that time, blasting the album on my car stereo, & living every note as they rose into the vivid, intensely-blue, Southwestern sky. But as big of a fan as I was of U2, I'm not sure that I had ever seen them in concert. (Maybe at a local church, when they first started-out?) But that was to finally change when U2 announced their Joshua Tree 30th Anniversary Tour, & my husband & I had tickets to see them in St. Louis, on September 16, 2017. But due to the acquittal of Officer Jason Stockley, in the shooting death of Anthony Lamar Smith, & the subsequent peaceful protests that turned violent; it became the only date in which U2 cancelled their concert. We went to St. Louis, anyway, & walked around the Arch, & downtown. I remember conversing with some homeless people in a park. And overall, it was actually quite quiet, that evening, & we didn't have any problems. But here we are, still not having seen U2. And especially not having heard them perform The Joshua Tree. Maybe some day...
The band that has a politician as their singer had become increasingly less interesting after issuing Rattle and Hum (and I think that is the point when the singer became the politician), so no surprise here: it's been a downward spiral since 1988 when my idols were no longer my heroes who performed that fantastic gig that became the Under a Blood Red Sky album. So yes, Rick, I am one of those people 4:54 ðŸ˜‹

No doubt U2 had to make a hard decision, but for the first time they appear to have put the U2 machine in front of the music or any of the four members. Unfortunately the shows can only really be a commercial success, which they will be, but the real damage will be to the unique romantic notion of the 4 members of the band powerful, â€˜in the soundâ€™, an unshakable force that exists because of that famous and by now mythical â€˜4 legged tableâ€™. Went to see U2 with friends, in Tampa Florida, on my Birthday in 1987. The moon was full and it was cold out. It was the best concert I have ever attended.
Larry is the most down to earth guy in this band by far. I met him backstage at Giant stadium during the Achtung Baby tour. I had a good friend who owned a record store and did rigging for Meadowlands shows I went with him. After the show there were two parties going on â€¦.one that the band was hosting supposedly and the other was a Paul McGuinness fÃªte. The band members and the entourage were bouncing back-and-forth between these two parties underneath the stands in the end zone where the band was set up. Noted photographer, Anton Corbin was prancing around with the best looking girls. Not bad for a guy whoâ€™s a virtual midget and pretty strange looking. I think the Edge was on the edge of his divorce at the time while Bono and Adam were busy with the parties.Â   Meanwhile there was a pretty high ceiling back there and a lot of empty space as you might imagine under a grandstand. The parties were going on in these big makeshift tented areas for privacy I would imagine. Right across from the parties back toward the stage, there was kind of a big walkway for forklifts and other thing. When I turned around, Larry was sitting on a rather large travel case. He was wearing a T-shirt and jeans and looking pretty sullen. I popped up on the other end of the case. Pretty sure I was wearing the same thing, v-neck t-shirt and jeans. We were roughly the same age. It was warm outside and we began to talk â€¦he couldnâ€™t have been more accommodating and very easy to talk to. He was married, and I think he had already started his family. He had absolutely zero interest in the parties.Â   During this tour, apparently what he had been doing right after shows was riding his motorcycle, a Harley Davidson I think to the next venue. In this case, Washington DC. As it turns out, we were sitting on the case that held the motorcycle. Apparently next to us there was another case, holding a similar motorcycle. This other motorcycle was for a companion/bodyguard on the tour who would ride with Larry to safeguard his trips. As luck would have it â€¦it started to drizzle after the show. Larry was waiting for confirmation to hop on the bike and get out of there. A short while later Paul McGuinness came over to let him know there would be no motorcycle trip tonight and he handed us some champagne bottles. Iâ€™m assuming Paul did not want to be the manager of Def Leppard if you get my drift. Larry was not happy at all about the decision, and was not interested in joining the parties across the way. He talked to me for a little while longer and then I believe he went straight back to the hotel.Â   Like everybody on here Iâ€™ve been a fan of that band for a long time, but have lost interest over the years. Quite frankly, canâ€™t believe the prices Bono is getting for Tickets during his run at the Beacon theater here in New York. Heâ€™s starting to morph into the Iranian dude that wrote the Satanic verses â€¦Maybe people are spending all their China flu money on those tickets. I saw U2 on their first tour here. I still have all the early import singles, the remixes everything in pristine condition from the first three albums. I also have a giant unforgettable fire poster, a promo poster for the album. The kind that used to hang in the record stores. I believe I saw them at the Palladium downtown NYC shortly after they ripped out all the seats. It was packed, it was good, it was exciting. Bono climbed up on the PA system, waving some kind of flag or something at that point it was already getting a little obnoxious. I remember the edge looking up at him thinking dude youâ€™re gonna take a tumble one of these days.  Then as time went by and Bono got more political this band in my opinion begin to lose their mojo. I quickly lost interestâ€¦ Left-wing, politics, are juvenile, and all the woke bullshit that ensues is destructive. No band is as close to my heart as U2. From first hearing them on an underground radio station from San Francisco, to first seeing them on the Tom Snyder show, U2 was my band. Before that, music was what everyone else enjoyed and I listened too. One of the first images that comes to my mind in regards to U2 is Larry playing the intro to Sunday Bloody Sunday at Redrocks or him riding a horse with a drum on his back through the winter of Sweeden. How important is Larry to me in the whole of U2. More important than Elvis Aaron Presley was to rock'n roll in my eyes, and I LOVE Elvis. No one member of U2 is more important than the next. U2 was THE band that made me pick up music and guitar - I was born in 93 and the release that changed my life was Slane Castle's live DVD. By watching that gig/performance countless times, my life changed. And yes, I studied back their catalog since the beginning and even when I started not enjoying their newer albums as much, I always respected the way they tried to change and keep their identity at the same time. It's also impossible to think about touring/big shows without recognizing U2's importance in this (the Zoo TV tour was monumental here). I respect them a lot, respect and enjoy their music and lose count to the amount of stuff I see other bands going for/doing that wasn't started by them.  Having said all this, they should stop. If not now, soon. If they want to make a residency in Vegas, fine; if they don't all agree, don't. And Larry has expressed a few times over the years the will to kind of stop the band - no new stuff, no big and long tours. Bono is, and has been, pushing for a while. But it's just not right. It's sad to see, not only a super influential band, but the band that changed my life not be able to recognize that it's time to slow down, stop completely or just change the approach to music. I ABSOLUTELY love your channel Rick; I access your INCREDIBLE information, track isolation deconstruction & opinions OFTEN.  However, indeed, your "rant" (as you humbly made mention to) I DO accept, but solely as 'opinion' or 'commentary'.  May I explain?  Coming from being a drummer myself, since 14 years of age...then much, much later in my life (age 55) having to go under the sharp knife and brave an "A.L.I.F." (Anterior approach to Lumbar Interbody Fusion) of the L4/L5 Disc, was one of the scariest, but needed, moments of my life.  Kudos & High Congratulations to the IMPECCABLE staff of Cedars-Sinai of Los Angeles/Marina del Rey and renowned USC Tojans/L.A. Dodgers Spinal Surgeon Dr. Robert Watkins, MD...this procedure...this MAJOR OPERATION, which also included a highly experienced Vascular Surgeon to "CUTT-My-GUTT-Open" to allow Watkins to approach the highly degenerated disc at the aforementioned L4/L5 section; replace it with a bone grafted apparatus, install 6 titanium screws & end plate for stability...saved my ability to walk, sit & stand...and yes, it can give "back" the ability for a drummer in his early to mid 60s (Mr. Larry Mullen, Jr.) to sit on his drum throne....and play, once again.  It is my dear hope, that Mullen, the original founder of U2, undergoes the most successful spinal surgery ever; whether he chooses a skilled surgical staff in the UK, or here in the US.  Spinal Surgery is no cake-walk...BUT...as mentioned, this may just be able to put HIM "back" where he belongs...AND...loves to be, in the Drummer's Seat, of U2.  Thank you Rick.  BolsaChicaRadio

As a U2 fan since 1983, I'm also distraught at the notion of the band taking the stage without Larry Mullen Jr. after all this time. But in fairness to the band, back in December Larry told the Washington Post that he probably wouldn't tour with U2 in 2023 if they decided to hit the road. He mentioned needing surgery and time to recover, but his comments also suggested he may be done with touring altogether. He said, "You only do this if youâ€™re having the best time, and not everyone is going to make it because the price is so high." I suspect that the Las Vegas gigs were lined up even in December and Larry was setting the stage for his future with U2, which is to remain a creative writing and recording member, but not touring. If that is what he wants, then there are only two options: U2 live with a different drummer, or no U2 shows ever.
I have no problem with this honestly. They've advertised they're doing a residency, that's fine; they've announced a key band member won't be there, that's a shame but it's fine. Has anyone considered possible obligations due to contract? Every band to a record company is a 'product' which needs to make revenue. Having been quiet for so long, maybe they've been put under pressure, or this new manager was, to give a sign of life and make money flow. In most instances it's about the output of recorded work (albums, singles), but revenue can of course be generated through concerts as well. Maybe U2 is doing this because they 'had to', maybe this was planned before Larry Mullen turned unable to play and the whole thing was too expensive, or too damaging for their reputation to call off. Many bands that go into their 'legacy-phase' keep on playing because of the economic incentive, not because of any creative juices.

Almost didnâ€™t get tickets even though I had Ticketmaster on speed dial and kept hitting redial at midnight when the tickets went on sale. Finally got through and only nosebleed tickets behind the stage were left, so I took them. We showed up as early as theyâ€™d let us in, several hours before the show, to watch the setup and sound check. A roadie came over to us and said, â€œAre these really your seats?â€ And we were like, â€œYesâ€. He said, â€œShow me your ticketsâ€. So we handed them over, and he goes, â€œWow, these suckâ€. Then he ripped them up, and gave us new tickets, and said, â€œThe band saved these for their real fansâ€ as he handed us front row center tickets. We couldnâ€™t believe it. They took us down and we were literally right next to the stage. The yellow jacket security guys formed a wall behind us when the concert started, so we didnâ€™t even have to deal with a crowd pressing us into the stage. Best concert ever. We saw them again when they came through for the stadium tour, but nothing will beat that original time ever. Great band, and even better live. I am a longtime U2 fan, back to early 80's in War/Unforgettable Fire era.  What I think we may be missing here is U2 doing something we are not expecting, as they are about pushing boundaries, especially in their live shows.  They are a live band, in that their songs sound better live, compared to their studio counterparts - They refine the songs on the road - Bad, Streets, New Years Day etc.  The Sphere is a multimedia exeprience, including smells from what I have read, and the Edge recently said they are going to take advantage of the innovation and push the boundaries.  I understand Larry Mullen Jr has been injured for a long time and during Covid it came to light just how bad he is, so he said he is not playing in 2023 as he needs to heal up.  With that being said, I am not sure they will have a live drummer to replace him, as they probably will use some tech to have his part played(even by him in video), kind of like a further extention of what they did on the Experience tour where they played along with video parts too.  Whatever the case, I am sure it is going to push boundaries and expectations.

It was actually each user who made it possible for the U2 album to appear on their devices. U2 released the album for free and Apple did this by automatically making it â€œownedâ€ by everyone who had an iTunes account. If a user had their settings for â€œautomatically download owned songsâ€ turned on got the album downloaded.

Dear Rick,  Interesting coincidence.  A little over a week ago I re-watched your clip about "Drowning Man", at the beginning of which you mention the many people who hate U2.  For some reason I felt compelled to write several paragraphs in the comments about why even as a listener I could see the haters' points of view.   Your rant here reflects much of my exasperation.   For a group that largely defined 80's post-punk and 90's post-grunge, catapulting from college-radio underground to the top of the world, they've done some embarrassing and remarkably insecure things.  I can empathize with a man who's in pain, but that seems beside the point: it's this decision by U2 as a group that prompts this discussion.

Was this actually an argument in good faith? U2 is a band, yes, but also a machine. Possibly hundreds of people are responsible for putting on their shows either through design, construction, testing, etc. The venue probably sunk substantial costs dedicating their state-of-the-art stage to U2's slot. It could be that, due to the upfront costs, they had no choice but to put on the show to recoup their substantial investment. This is the inevitable consequence of having amazing stage experiences--the show must go on.  It's going to be okay for people to enjoy themselves at the show even if it's not Larry. 0:52 Fantastic drummer
In football, all the great ones (Namath, Favre, Esiason, Rogers, and now Brady) tend to hang on one season too long and wind up tarnishing their legacy.  In rock music, it's even worse.  The great ones hang on DECADES too long and wind up sounding like a Vegas lounge act.  The Stones should have called it quits at the turn of the millenium.  Chicago has only three original members left, and they're still hanging on, even though they don't sound anything like they used to.  Fleetwood Mac is a never-ending soap opera.  (I can sing higher than Stevie Nicks, and I'm a baritone!)  The Eagles should have wrapped it up after Glenn Frey passed away.  Bruce Springsteen's voice is a mere shadow of what it used to be.  And now U2 is applying a defibrillator to themselves.  Guys--you're not in your 20's anymore.  Find a shred of dignity and make a graceful exit.
I like the passion. But U2 and controversy go hand in hand. Rattle is certainly not the most controversial album, either. Pop was. But here's a band with notoriously minimal drama, and all the money is in playing live right now. James Dolan is a spoiled brat rich kid who's once again in the media for all the wrong reasons, so maybe this is also him pushing his businesses to take the stink off those board room meetings, who knows. The question is why is the drummer not playing with them? Maybe because he's recouping form surgery... Is this that big of a deal? They ain't no spring chickens so timetables are not quite as reliable as, let's say Baseball players. Even after 30 the docs just can't know, so they "play it by ear..." You are signing on for a residency for $10mil. People are going to want guarantees the show will go on, so they need to know it will even if a sub is needed.   Now, if that's the deal they all signed, there is no drama here. There are contracts and obligations that need to be met. This is the brave new world. Bands like U2 don't have the revenue stream form royalties anymore. The part of the story we are all missing is the fact that U2 are doing a residency for $10 mil signing bonus up front, and 90% of the gate for 12 shows. Come on, Rick, this is the info I expect to get when I come here. And the internet is a beautiful thing. It doesn't matter when an album came out. It's all out there for 7 billion to enjoy or dismiss. So they know what they're doing. They need to fill 17k seats for 12 shows and still have songs left in the tank. Like, how much can they get for Joshua Tree? Those fans are of an age where they have disposable incomes all over the place and Vegas is very, very good at targeting people with cash burning a hole in their pocket. On the basis of Achtung Baby they can gauge what every single other album will do, or if they should do albums vs just a setlist, as well as how much they should demand for their next residency.
Replacing a drummer in an old band is like replacing the brakes in an old car.  They just wear out.  Dick Dale could burn out a drummer in a year.
Huge U2 fan here. I was turned on to U2 back in 1981 by a foreign exchange student from Dublin. He worked at the Hilton in Washington DC; I was a junior in high school. He had a cassette tape and recorder from U2 playing on the hill behind his house! Do you guys remember the portable tape recorders that you needed 2 fingers to press the buttons to "record"? Yeah, that's how old I am! One day he dragged me into the sporting goods room and made me listen to U2 and I was forever hooked. A few months later I heard an announcement on radio station 99.1 WHFS about U2 playing Richie Coliseum at U of MD. I cut school and saw them at this 1950's built college gymnasium with the bench seats that pulled out from the wall. I think there were maybe 60 people at the show, and they played a few songs twice! I have never missed a show and have seen most shows more than once. I will be selling a kidney on Ebay to fund the U2 Vegas trip. I hope to see you there, Rick. BTW.. absolutely LOVE your channel and I don't play any instruments!

I hear you Rick.  I understand your frustration, and I share some of it.  Was there no way to hold off this gig until Larry could perform?  Did the new manager sign a contract that prevented such a cancellation and delay?  It's all possible.     Reading from sources on line, such the Irish Times, they are saying that Larry need surgery due to some problems in his neck and elbows.   As a person who has also suffered neck vertebrae problems, such a thing is very painful and debilitating.  I'm a guitar player, and I would venture that a drummer is really going to suffer from such problems.  I don't know the extent of what his condition is.  It very well may be that the elbow issue is related to his neck issue.  For me, the surgery went very well, and recovery took some time, as your head is help up by a neck brace in order to relax your neck muscles, all the while waiting for the healing from the surgery.   I wish Larry the best.     I love U2.  I started listening to them in college back in 1984, and have loved their music and messages since then. I have to mention that I've seen Bono live on a couple of TV shows, and he looks older than his years.  I hope he is well.  He has been an inspiration human being to me, and to all of his fans who share his views.
Maybe there's a reason behind him not joining them. I doubt that he's being excluded. Maybe he just doesn't want to do it and the rest of them do. They are being up front about him not playing with them. I don't see what the BFD is.
I live now in Berlin. ZooStation is a place I go as a resident. Saw the show in Miami in 1991. Not as good as The Joshua Tree show in 1987. But they were onto something. They always were back then. I think it's a fine criticism - basically, why not wait and reschedule the dates at this state-of-the-art venue? I think they are all getting older and feeling the finality of their careers. I can't blame them for wanting to dwell in the light a little longer before hitting the twilights of their careers - we have seen bands like the Stones, The Who and Aerosmith go on with credible effect. It's cool younger kids can see these bands still. One thing about U2 - they have had the rarity and the gift of preserving their friendship, partnership and entire band with all original members for 4 incredible decades. To me, it's not about the need to know when to stop, it's about appreciating them while they are here still doing it for us. The second a member goes, it's just not U2 anymore. We've gotten the ACTUAL U2 for 40 years! That is just nuts, and all their interesting missteps aside, they put on the best live show ever, pound for pound, that can go toe to toe with any rock greats. They care a lot about the fans and the fan experience, which shows. That being said, why not just wait for Larry? Sure, a lot of money is tied up, but you can't tell me that another artists wouldn't gladly slip into those dates, freeing U2 of any contractual obligation and giving Larry time to heal so he can come back ready for the gigs at the Sphere. Do the right thing, boys!

Maybe it's a musician's perspective a little bit to understand more fully the contribution of each band member to the entity, beyond just what is visible during the 3 hours on the stage. I feel that there are some bands where one or two members are the figureheads or primary creators and maybe other members might be less integral to the bands identity. U2 is so unique in the "topsy, turvy world of rock and roll" for remaining 4 original members, 4 characters, 4 friends...It just feels like they should not present themselves as U2 without Larry. Yes, a different drummer could play Larry's drum parts spot on...not the point. Almost any other band could get away with continuing on minus certain members, not U2. It will diminish their identity to MANY of us lifelong fans. Some ChatGPT support on how to pronounce "Achtung".  (checked by a native German) :)   Start with the "ah" sound as in "father."   Pronounce the "ch" sound by exhaling sharply and making a sound similar to clearing your throat. This sound is made by moving the back of your tongue up towards the soft palate.   Next, add a short and crisp "t" sound immediately after the "ch" sound.   Finally, end with the "ung" sound, which is similar to the "oong" sound in "sung."   Putting it all together, the correct pronunciation of "Achtung" would be "ah-ch-toong".

Hey Rick, I don't comment very often, but this time I feel inclined to. You'll probably not read this, although I hope you do.  First of all: I totally get where you're coming from. Although I was born in '89 and don't listen to U2 very often these days, I grew up with and have loved their music. And as with most bands, I prefer the original line-ups.  But as someone from the Netherlands, it's a big deal and very cool to see someone as Bram van den Berg getting such a prolific gig. He's a great drummer and a nice guy, who's has done some awesome stuff here in the Netherlands. Getting to fill in for U2 is a huge deal for the Dutch music scene. You won't feel that sentiment like I do, but it's a pity you overlook the fact that a drummer who's unknown to most of the world gets such a great gig and just shrug him off as "some fill in drummer". I get there is an angry story from your side, but the positive story of the underdog musician getting the gig gets overlooked.  And we're missing context. Maybe Larry Mullen Jr. wanted this. If I were unable to play for some reason, I wouldn't want my band to stop working in the meantime. Like Dusty Hill wanted his guitar tech to take over bass duties. And if this is what he wants for the band, who are we to tell him he's wrong?  Once again, totally get where you're coming from, but I think there's a lot more to this ðŸ™‚

Jeez, calm down everyone! Bands replace performing musicians all the time, on either a full-time or temporary basis, especially the "legacy" bands that reunite and tour on an almost annual basis. Now I am NOT a U-2 fan but that is besides the point. If Bono and the boyz want to use other musicians for a tour or residency, than more power to them. Better to keep playing and performing rather than stagnating, and certainly better than waiting for an indefinite time period for the recovery of a band member with obvious health problems that may require a long rehabilitation and continuing treatment. Consider too, that playing drums and percussion can be a difficult task for older musicians (Rick knows that, I think!) particularly for those with a health issue or physical infirmity. So Rick's stance seem quite curious to me.

Devil's advocate here, but I don't think this is as tragic as it's seems.  Larry's exclusion from this gig was choice made months ago, if not more, and the choice was his.  I find him to be a man of great integrity to allow himself to sit out while the band that has been his life continues.  True, U2's sound weighs heavily on LMJr's drumming, but so was Bill Wyman's influence on the Rolling Stones sound, ...I don't remember anyone lamenting, or "ranting" when Bill decided to call it a day, and the Stones are still doing quite well.   For all we know LMJr wants to let his body heal, perhaps he has other health problems we don't know about, or wants to spend his golden days with family, again...integrity. It's not the first time U2 did a major project without one of its members. As others here have already mentioned, there was an Australian gig that Adam Clayton missed on the ZooTV Tour in '93 because of too much partying. It was a fairly critical show, too, a technical dry-run for a second show that would be broadcast live globally via satellite and would later be released on various home video formats. A roadie covered for Adam that night, wearing a baseball cap to hide the fact that he was a last-minute substitute. As I understand it, the incident caused Adam to seriously reevaluate his priorities and clean up his act.   Also, I believe Larry's back issues flared up rather infamously during the recording of the Pop album in '96, and the band continued without him for a time using drum loops and such. If I'm remembering correctly, the injury was one of the reasons why U2 always felt the album's production was rushed and unfocused, and that not enough time was spent rehearsing for the pre-booked PopMart Tour kicking off in the following Spring.
Larry said in an interview last year that due to health issues he wouldn't be touring with the band this year.  He even said in the same interview that the band had things in the works.  The guys aren't getting any younger and who knows if they were to wait around for Larry's physical condition to improve if they would ever play again.  I think this is an enormous overreaction.  It's not an ideal situation, but there are extenuating circumstances at play.
Have a cigar and relax. I can't see why this is a problem if Larry needs surgery, why is a fill in wrong. The Beatles did it back in the day.   I guess the contract was done and dusted. If anything it's a shedload of money as well.
As a fellow Dutchman: It is a cashgrab. Larry also will get millions. And let 'our' Bram have his moment with the band for some fixed fee. Everybody happy. U2 as we knew it is long gone.

And that's why the music business is in the horrific state that it has been in for the last twenty years.  Quite honestly, the modern audiences killed the art.

Beloved Rick, I really think you are exaggerating about that. I mean, yes the bands should be considered as one. But if someone has health issues it's not that questionable to replace for just one gig. No one can ever know the desire of the other members to play their songs and communicate with their audience, and they have every right to do so. Now, U2 have sold out their heart and soul long before, that's my opinion, and that apple thing very rightfully drawn the global hate towards them because it was so so so offensive. But the replacement thing is not for us to judge. It would be different if they replaced their drummer for other than health reasons.   The artists in general should have the right to do whatever move needed to transmit their signal, that's not for the audience to judge. Even if they did that gig all four of them, it would also be a sell out. They have made a very conscious decision to prioritize money over music, that's the critique, not their internal decisions. They have altered the context of the message they try to send to the audience over the years with the perspective how to make more money. That's the sellout. And they are all four responsible about that.  You refer to John Lennon, but there can be no similarity. He wanted to transmit the truth from his songs at all costs, being the most successful person in music ever. He risked everything for that.  Of course, Rush let's say, would never have a concert other than an honourable concert to Neil without him, but they have kept true to themselves throughout the whole journey. Freedom of choice without judging from the audience is one thing, and sell out is another. And by the way, sell out is not changing the style etc, because that is natural progression. Genesis made spectacular albums after Peter Gabriel's departure. Peter Gabriel did as well. Genesis split and that was for good as it turned out.  Anyway, change is good, sellout is bad, that's my point.

One must not forget that even that madly popular and inseparable (at the time) unit The Beatles had to play part of a world tour in 1964 without Ringo. So one can't be too critical on that account. However, my main comment relates to the mere fact of a group like U2 contracting into a Las Vegas residency. Not just a U2 issue of course, but it can only be because it is much cheaper and you make more money when the fans to travel to see you rather than you going to entertain them where they live. A (dollar) sign of the times I suppose.
Seems to me a "residency" in Las Vegas is associated with some kind of "entrapment" and leads to a death spiral. Elvis, Wayne Newton (Yeah he is still doing it, has plenty of money, but look at him! Why is he still out there until he dies on stage??) Sinatra and so many others. I agree.... REALLY?? How rich, or popular you are has nothing to do with the types of contractual entrapments artists have always fell prey to. It extends beyond just artists to political figures, or just about anyone with any influence if they are not extremely guarded and protective of themselves. Achtung Baby for me is one of the best records of all time and the one that influenced me the most. And it's not just the songs, it's the sonics too. To me, it always sounds like the Berlin of the early 90's resonating with the Berlin of the 20's and 30's. The Fly must have one of my favourite guitar solo's of all time. It's not a difficult solo in terms of notes, but the sound is sheer genius. I still try to capture that exact sound on my guitar to this day. No idea how they got that sound on the record.

Bono put a book out and one of the venues he was doing a book tour on was The Beacon- which Dolan owns (he also owns MSG, Beacon, Radio City Music Hall, The Knicks, and The Rangers and a couple of other venues and sold off Cablevision for billions of dollars). Bono's one Beacon show wound up in the hands of resellers and the tix were going for crazy amounts of money. Just to watch Bono read from a book! So it's pretty obvious Bono and Dolan are bros, and Bono's pretty much using the U2 brand to help bring people from all over (insert the "if we build it they will come" soundbite). I'm sure Billy Joel will also be playing the Sphere because he locked into a contract with Dolan years ago to do a lucrative MSG residency. This is a powerful guy -he renovated MSG and The Beacon, and basically made the city move the train system around him. He was also in the news for kicking a mom out escorting her kid on a FIELD TRIP to a Rockettes Christmas show - because she also happened to be working for a law firm that's suing him, and identified her with facial recognition software. One, is Larry cool with it?  Maybe he's going to make it later in the residency.  Maybe it'll be a part of his recovery.  Who knows, but if he really deep down is cool, then I'm cool. U2 featuring Danny Carey?  Meg White?  Phil Collins?  Ringo??  There's a lot of potential there, if they take advantage of it.

Love your stuff, but had to chime in here -   1. If Larry Mullen Jr is unable to perform at this time, one would have to assume he loves the band too much to want to hold them back. I'm sure he'll return if/when he's able, but you can't bust their chops for trying to keep the flame alight. None of them are getting any younger - if they want to rock, so be it!   2. I happen to know Bram van den Berg and he's not just a 'fill in'. He's been one of the most successful drummers in Holland for decades (while still being pretty young), having headlined arenas (and beyond) with his original band Krezip, as well as The Dutch Queen tribute (that has also played to MANY massive crowds) and lots of other cool projects (including a stint with me about 10 years ago). I fell in love with him at our first soundcheck - he came in prepared and carefree. Bram has pocket for days and an easy-coolness about him that can't be denied. No wonder he got the call! When I started hearing about this from my Dutch peeps (most working musicians) this week, everyone was in agreement that he was a great choice for such an important gig. I truly love L.M. Jr as much as anyone and agree he's an absoltely singular drummer and arranger, but Bram will do everyone proud 100%. Let's wish them success.

It's not always as simple as not listening to it. For example, a lot of car systems are set up to start playing automatically when they connect. Since iOS doesn't let you set default apps, if you use something like Spotify, it won't play, but whatever the default iOS music app is will, and if that album is all you have, then it plays! It happens on my wife's phone all the time. We get in the car, and there is U2. She's even deleted it, and it seems to come back. I'm not sure if it is synced with iCloud or something to do with updates.

With other bands, the line up can change and it is no big deal. But with U2 this is not the case. For decades it has been, 'we are the band, and we will do this until it is not fun anymore.  There for a while it was not fun and we did not do anything, then we realized we actually missed all this.  Then we rediscovered some of the old stuff. This is a song we stopped playing, for a long time. But we found it's soul again. It's Sunday Blood Sunday.'  This is paraphrased from the 11.05.2001 Austin Texas show on the Elevation tour. For decades this was a band that either did it all together or did not do it at all.

When they made the Pop album in 1996-97, McGuinness famously said that it was a case of â€œToo many cooks in the kitchenâ€ as to why the album sounded like an unfinished work (75% of that album is some of their strongest material ever). Only saw U2 once - around 1980 - at the Agora Ballroom in Atlanta. This was their first American tour. Untrue.  An example: Chicago replaced (fired) their drummer (Dan Seraphine), after 30 years - despite being one of the 3 founders (of the original 7 - incidentally none with the band now). Seraphine defined a new type of rock-n-roll drumming, as a lead voice, bombastic fills and all. So identifiable as the original '70s sound. Subsequent drummers were very good, even great - but the sound was different.  Nobody cared.  Fans went and didn't even know the difference, or cared quite frankly (they still go). The Beatles played a few live dates with a substitute drummer when Ringo was ill.  This is hard for some musicians to accept, but most non-musicians don't care who the drummer is.  Or any the other musicians, either.  Which is why so many singers in a band leave the band for solo careers... when it dawns on them that most non-musicians don't care who the other other band members are, so why split the take when one can hire musicians and pay them a salary?  Which is not to say that all singers who leave their band for a solo career make it, but probably more do than don't.  So, sorry, Rick, and yes, a "substitute drummer" may very well be insufficiently creative to come up with unique drum grooves on new songs.  But I"m sure the substitute drummer will be able to play all of Mullen's drum grooves on their existing songs just as well or at least well enough that no one will care.  Just as the Rolling Stones are really Mick and Keith, U2 is really Bono and the Edge.  I remember, in U2's early days, a running joke in NME or some British music paper, where various of the writers would ask, "What does Adam Clayton do?"  Mullen is a creative drummer, but Clayton is your average cookie cutter bassist, could be replace with any competent bassist in a heartbeat.

This is a symptom of Front Man Syndrome....people thinking Bono (& perhaps The Edge) are the only important part of the band. Arguably, each album alone: Boy (1980), October (1981), War (1983), Under A Blood Red Sky (1983), Unforgettable Fire (1984), Wide Awake in America (1985), The Joshua Tree (1987), could be the definition of "MASTERPIECE." And what is truly astonishing is that those were consecutive album releases. Everything U2 had ever recorded up to that point in time was like that. Genius. Then came Rattle and Hum (1988), and it was welcomed, and it had its own league. Then came Achtung Baby (1991), and after The Fly it was hard to get to the end of the record just to listen to Love is Blindness and think that it had been worth the wait. Achtung Baby was produced by Steve Lillywhite, Daniel Lanois and Brian Eno. Those names solely should have gathered legions of U2 fans around Achtung Baby, back in 1991. So, I have 7 + 2 U2 albums, and that is it. I am happy they found new listeners.

Ok, yes we are of a similar age Rick and I heartily agree.  This happened with the last Black Sabbath gigs and the obviously missing Bill Ward. His replacement was great, BUT... The band members are about 10 years older than me, and I feel like I've gone through a good chunk of my life with their music. I'll say this for U2, they are willing to try sh*t.  Sometimes it's spectacularly great--as in how they changed their sound for Achtung Baby!--and sometimes it bombs, like the Apple fiasco.  This year they are trying two things that strike me as risky: the Vegas residency without LMJ and "Songs of Surrender."  I have no idea how the residency will turn out, and the whole "Songs of Surrender" thing strikes me as anathema to the post-punk sound those songs emerged from, but I haven't heard it all yet.  But I'm happy they are willing to go out and try sh*t rather than trod down the same road others have before them.  I wish more folks were willing to take the risks they do.

My initial reaction when I heard Larry was out for this was much the same as Rick's, but I think we're missing the weight of the machinery that was already set in motion behind the curtain.  Given that this was announced on such a huge stage (at such a huge cost) I would guess that this has been in the works for a while and they had every intention of doing it as the quartet they've been for decades. Following that either Larry tried to proceed with some treatments with the intent of being ready for the show but the procedure and/or recovery is not going as well as expected (w.r.t. the opening schedule for The Sphere) or something came up that necessitated treatment without the necessary recovery time to fulfill the contractual obligations.  Larry's parts and feel are crucial ingredients in the U2 sound - but a live gig is not a writing session. I'm sure that with the resources at their disposal, U2 ought to be able to find someone with the ability to fill in and do it justice for a few shows - somewhat constraining the setlist and allowing them to hone in during rehearsal. It won't be the same, but I'm sure it'll still be spectacular.  Personally I'm just glad I saw them back in 2010 on the 360 tour.

Well, Larry's got some health problems now, which may have cropped up after this whole Las Vegas thing was arranged. So, the show must go on, as they say. He can't play it right now, and I'm sure there are thousands of professional drummers who can play every single one of LMJr's drum parts. As unique as The Edge is, I'm sure there are legions of guitarists who have sorted out what he's doing on those recordings. Perhaps the only "irreplaceable" member is Bono, because he has such a distinctive voice and stage presence. Fans would feel cheated if U2 came out on stage, but rather than Bono, you had Joe the Singer up there. Actually, I think the Edge has some other guy playing second guitar below stage, so there's already some stand-ins at hand. Adam Clayton is a good bassist, but you could swap in another guy pretty seamlessly. So, big deal, they hired a different drummer out of necessity. If U2 continues to perform in the coming years, this will be an ongoing issue potentially, as with age comes health challenges.

Maybe it's just because my favorite band still tours and has replaced 3/5 of their original lineup over the years, but this seems like an overreaction to me. Their original drummer is considered one of the most influential drummers of the genre, but if I'm being honest, I think the current drummer is even better. Their current bassist is a solid upgrade over the original, and the current guitarist isn't exactly a downgrade.    Maybe if Larry Mullen was publicly pissed off about it, that would be one thing, but as far as I can tell, he's cool with it. Dude's 61 years old with elbow issues. I've heard from some of the faster/harder drummers that it's just not possible to keep at those paces forever. Mullen almost certainly doesn't put the same stress on his body that they do, but I've known guys in their 20s that had to retire for wrist issues. I could certainly imagine him being comfortable with his contributions and not wanting to derail the band over his health.

Drummers sadly are often the most overlooked musicians in any band. Black Sabbath's final tour featured three of the four original members, but had a fill in drummer rather than Bill Ward. And honestly, Bill Ward's jazz influenced style was as integral to their sound as Tony Iommi's guitar wizardry, Geezer Butler's innovative bass work, and Ozzy Osbourne's unique vocal approach. I dare say U2 is just as much a result of ALL the original musicians.
I love U2. Was lucky enough to finally see them back in 2017 in Seattle. Without the whole band, I'm just not interested. Being a residency in Vegas? Even less interested.

I don't remember any of the songs from their albums after Achtung Baby.  Mostly just unoriginal drivel and neutered drums.  I remember listening to the "War" album and the heavy, distinct beat and raw sound.  "Like a Song" is drums personified.  It was mesmerizing.  As much as Edge defines the U2 sound, Mullen Jr. was the backbone of their music.  In a way, once his drumming disappeared into the cacophony of the later songs, he was gone.  What they're doing to his legacy now just seems like a continuation of where they were going.  I know that's not the case but there is some sort of macabre symmetry to what they are doing now.  Sigh.

It takes full immersion to a whole new level and promises an audio visual experience unlike anything else on earth. 160,000 3d beamforming speakers covering 360Â° of the internal skin. Sound will even come from the flooring. Add in the largest curved screen on earth forming an internal 8k resolution skin, holographic technology, and the sheer possibilities of such a game changing venue ... then U2 and Achtung Baby are 'exactly' the kind of band and album that lends itself to what will be an extraordinarily immersive and artistic experience. Compare the fates of two bands that took different courses. The Who kept going after Keith Moon's death but were never the same. They couldn't replace Moon's power and drive that he gave to the music and they slowly faded into a tribute band of themselves. Led Zeppelin stopped cold when John Bonham died. And because they didn't adulterate their sound with  another drummer, their entire catalogue is still treasured to this day.

Apps that people wanted to always be on their phones that were life changing, that leveled sensory access like never before were getting automatically moved off the phone to make room for mandatory updating and other stuff like this not well thought out marking scheme.   Having said all this, I do feel for the stranger who is filling in.  He's probably a professional just doing his job.

I think what is missing here is what does LARRY think.  He'd probably hate to be the guy that is holding back the other 3 members of the band - maybe not, but there's that possibility.  Given the brotherhood of the band, I can't imagine that this would be a long-term replacement unless it HAD to be.  I first heard Where The Streets... at 8 years old when it came out - instant goosebumps.  Having read their books, owned all their albums, and having Achtung Baby artwork in my house, I'm a pretty big fan.  I imagine that much more thought and discussion went into this than the Apple debacle - but I feel like we have to somewhat give their brotherhood the benefit of the doubt.  As for the Vegas angle - who cares if it's Vegas?  This doesn't immediately turn them into a caricature of themselves.  Vegas is already a destination for many people, so it's a somewhat democratic location for fans to come from afar to see them.  They're also in their 60s, so touring almost certainly takes a toll on the quality of their performances over time.  They also don't have to deal nearly as much with soundchecks/audio quality/audio issues if they can play the same place every night.  It might also give them the chance to try or do NEW things in a state-of-the-art venue that they couldn't pull off on tour.  Just my 2 cents - I'd definitely go see them with a different drummer as long as Larry WANTS it that way.

Rick, I rarely disagree with you, but you may want to think some aspects of this through a bit more before condemning the whole thing as sacrilege.    First, would you be this upset if Larry had retired like Bill Berry?  R.E.M. went on for many years without him, and nobody suffered for it, as they had people like Bill Rieflin holding it down admirably.    Or what if U2 had simply broken up, like the Beatles?  Abe Laboriel Jr. and Gregg Bissonette, among many others, have brought Ringo's parts to new audiences for decades now.  If you can approximate Ringo's sound faithfully, don't tell me no one can "sub" for Larry Mullen Jr., or that Achtung Baby is too unique of a drum performance.  I'm both a drummer AND a huge fan, and I can tell you there are thousands of seasoned professional drummers who could do this, and if you were blindfolded you would not know.  How about Matt Sherrod, who took over for Paul Hester in Crowded House?  Simon Phillips, Zakk Starkey and others with the WHO!!!    Would you be this upset if the fill in was Josh Freese?  Or Matt Cameron?  Bram van den Berg is a bit of an unknown, which makes the optics troubling, but you've gotta give a working musician a fair chance, Rick.  Come on.  Fans are big enough jerks to absolute legends like Neil Finn and Vince Gill when they fill in, this kid doesn't need you turning a giant chunk of the U2 fanbase against him before he plays a note.      The other thing is that, if this really has been in the works for a long time, then fulfilling it is not necessarily a money grab move or something to abandon on "principle."  Lots of working people are counting on this residency.   Just a few things to consider, from one cranky old musician to another.

It was billed as the 360 degree tour and I paid for tickets quite close to the stage for my wifeâ€™s birthday surprise. I imagined that the 360 degree referred to a rotating stage. Imagine my anger when it turned out that the stage did not rotate and even though we WERE close to the stage, we were BEHIND it! The only thing about it that was 360 degree was the giant wraparound video screen! Very occasionally, one of the band members would walk in a circle round the back of the stage and continue back to their position at the front. The sound was awful from our position and I felt really cheated. I concluded that the only reason they did this was to maximise their revenue. I tried to complain on their website the next day and was unable to do so without paying a fan club membership fee! I was outraged then and I am still angry about it now. I first saw U2 in April 1981, performing at small dive club in Pittsburgh called The Decade. Although barely bigger than my garage, The Decade featured an amazing run of future iconic bands, yet to break the big time (The Pretenders, The Police, The Ramones, Pat Bentar, Stevie Ray Vaughn, Red Hot Chili Peppers, etc.). U2 played most of the songs from their first album and then one song off the yet to be released October album ("I Fall Down"). At that point they ran out of songs, so they played the set again! I've seen U2 many times since, but none more electrifying than that first 1981 gig.

I'm not a huge U2 fan, and maybe that's why I'm having trouble understanding why their drummer's absence is such a deal-breaker.  Would I rather see The Who with Keith Moon, or Dream Theater with Mike Portnoy, or King Crimson with Bill Bruford, or Led Zeppelin with John Bonham, or Foo Fighters with Taylor Hawkins?  Yes to all of the above!  Nevertheless, I have enjoyed seeing each of these bands play live without their iconic drummer, either in person, or on a DVD or a YouTube video.  I wouldn't have wanted to miss those performances just because their iconic drummer had passed away, or had left the band, or wasn't available for whatever reason.  Even if U2's drummer is as key to their band as Neil Peart was to Rush (and I'm not convinced that he is, but maybe), well, I would still jump at the chance to see Geddy Lee and Alex Lifeson play Rush music with another drummer, because that would be better than not seeing them at all.

This reminds me of the Rolling Stones bass player replacement. Huge deal when you think of all the iconic bass lines of Bill Wyman. Darryl Jones is a phenomenal player too, and I know he's not a "member" of the Stones, but the remaining members are still the Rolling Stones. I'm sorry to say it (being a bass player myself), but the rhythm section of any band can be substituted for road work - that's the way a lot of the music business has treated them. It might not be fair, but probably less than half of the Stones fans cared. I'm going to guess that it will be similar with U2 fans regarding this replacement.

Rarely is there a match so perfectly made. Itâ€™s unfortunate that Larryâ€™s surgery will prevent him from participating but thatâ€™s life.  It happens to all of us, even rockstars.   U2 is more than a band.  They are a business that employs hundreds of people like roadies who have been with them since the 80s.  When the band isnâ€™t working, neither are they and in fact, havenâ€™t been working since 2019 before the pandemic shut down the concert industry.  This residency is an opportunity to provide them with income while the band completes their next album and mounts the tour to support it.  Sure, the band will make a boatload of money but thatâ€™s the way the industry works.   At the end of the day, all of the disappointment being expressed is just a knee jerk reaction that will be forgotten when the tickets go on sale.  Why would you deny yourself of what is guaranteed to be a memorable concert experience over something that  was unavoidable and doesnâ€™t effect you personally?

U2 has been living on the dark side for decades now.  Sad to see. Bono palling around with George W. Bush, Bill Gates, and all the rich and powerful, should have been the tip-off for people.  And Mullen, the lone Catholic in the group, and the most politically conservative, probably has had enough.   As Mullen said a couple of months ago, "I am autonomous and I value my autonomy. I don't sing from the same hymn sheet," Mullen said in a recent Washington Post interview, surrounding U2's upcoming Kennedy Center Honors. "I don't pray to the same version of God. So everyone has their limits."  On top of this, Mullen is taking time out to get his body back in order after suffering all the deterioration and damage that comes from playing drums passionately for 50 years.   So, a residency in Las Vegas (of all places) right now (when Mullen is working on his health) is the bridge too far for Mullen.  Good for him.    And, the hell with U2.  Really.

As someone who grew up with them from the time I was 10 yrs old  (1983),  This is absolutely horrible. I admit I got bored with their albums and especially Bono's pontificating from upon high about practically everything after around 2006, BUT, They always earned my respect for acting as a BAND. Not elevating individuals any more than they had to, Their entire existence. They've talked many times about being very hesitant or outright rejecting offers or circumstances to perform or participate in any band functions without ALL members present. Of course they've amended that over the decades in certain areas, But they stuck together and leaned on one another and rarely wavered for almost 47 years. I understand they want to stay relevant while they have the opportunity to, And keep their brand or vision for themselves out in the public eye. No one earns much anymore nor garners much attention anymore as far as legitimate musical acts, So I'm sure they want to get out there and pun intended, Drum up attention and make some cash while at it. Fine. But this to me just shows how far a band can fall, Whatever the reason over time, From their original vision, And heritage they helped create. As a former professional musician, I always respected and appreciated that they insist upon always elevating Adam and Larry as integral members, As equals. Now sadly, It looks to me like money and the slivers left of adulation left for them are the above all. I will never view or hear them the same way again.

Non-musicians have no idea how important the drummer is to the recorded sound of many bands. Led Zep quit forever after Bonham died. Smashing Pumpkins were the top band in the world when their drummer went to jail, and they released an album using electronic drums which tanked. G&R could never recreate the swingy-ness of their original drummer. Who cares about the Who as a recording band since Keith Moon died?   For live concerts/tours, stuff happens. Beatles toured Australia with jimmy Nicol when Ringo was sick. The Stones trundle on without Charlie (and Bill, and Mick Taylor, and BJ). Spinal Tap the same. I assume Dave Grohl is competent to hire another drummer for gigs, while playing on recordings. A Vegas residency is a pure money grab, and only 1% of paying customers are gonna care who's behind the drum kit.

There were talks for special Achtung Baby shows pre covid times and the construction of the MSG was set to finish in 2021, so most likely the band had planned to play these shows as usual with all 4 members of course. But then Covid happened and it all had to be delayed, and noone knew when life would become normal again. Time flew by and now this year Larry Mullen Jr. unfortunately has to have surgery and can't play, but of course they couldn't have known that when they planned the whole thing. Project management is not an easy thing. My guess is that these plans to play the "opener shows" for the MSG existed for years, and they didn't want to dip out now. Not just because of the concerts, but also because it has to be a huge thing for them to play inside of that sphere as the first band. Which is brand new technology. If they had planned a "normal" tour they would have most likely delayed it.
I guess this will be U3+1. Can't imagine what drummer they're gonna get to fill those shoes. Stu Copeland maybe? ;)  Oh wait, I know.... Ringo! :)

U2 is one of my favorite bands ever. I'm only 34, but discovering Achtung Baby and the ZOOTV Sydney performance pretty much changed my life around 15 years ago. I will always admire them, and I still consider No Line on the Horizon their last great successful attempt at something unique only they and their producers are capable of. A Vegas residency, to me, is in itself sad, but without Larry Mullen, it's an absolute waste. I truly love U2 and always will. But their desperation to say "relevant" has been their worst enemy for a while. No Line on the Horizon was an artistic triumph, but a commercial disappointment, and since then, they've seemed desperate to get their moment again, ignoring what people most expect: great, adventurous music. They will never be the trendiest band in the world, and that's just fine. It's a shame they seem to care so much about the spotlight they were so good at rejecting not so long ago. In any case, U2 will always be an amazing band, I just wish they realized it more often.

At least I have my memories, including a beautiful day in 1987: It was the day the Joshua Tree came out. It also happened to be the day I bought my first drum machine. I stopped by the mall afterward and bought the cassette. I remember heading home on the interstate, the windows down, the opening to â€œStreetsâ€ beginning, and looking over at the box my drum machine was in. POP was the last exciting U2 record but due to the ordinary 'Fuck Yeah' Yank's disapproval of it, it flopped.  Had U2 followed that path, they might have had a few shitty years up until say 2010, but they would've held on to their integrity and by this point been a revered band along the likes of The Cure and Depeche Mode. Let me play Devil's Advocate for a moment here: would you have the same problem if Larry Mullen Jr. had passed away? Bands, and particularly older bands, tour all the time with replacements for "irreplaceable" members - Led Zeppelin without John Bonham, The Who without Keith Moon. If the rest of the band want to keep on going but one member doesn't do you simply expect the whole band to retire? Storm in a teacup, much ado about nothing.
